text.headline: The birth of bioinformatics
text.text: Margaret Dayhoff and the origin of Genbank

text.headline: Frederick Sanger sequences insulin
text.text: Insulin becomes the first protein to have its sequence determined in the laboratory. This finding establishes that proteins are in fact comprised of a specific linear combination of amino acids with a definite structure.

text.headline: Margaret Dayhoff joins the NBRF
text.text: Dayhoff becomes the Associate Director of the new National Biomedical Research Foundatoin (NBRF) with the mission to explore applications of computers to biology and medicine.  She writes a series of FORTRAN programs to assemble complete proteins from fragments in a few minutes, which previously took months.

text.headline: Olga Kennard founds the CCDC
text.text: The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre is one of the earliest scientific databases and predecessor to the Protein Data Bank. Crystallography is the first biological science to take full advantage of digital computers in the 1950s.

text.headline: The Atlas of Protein Sequence and Structure
text.text: Dayhoff and Eck use computer programs they developed to gather and process all publicly available protein sequences, which they compile into a copyrighted book. The first volume contained 66 entries. The Atlas is stored and processed on punch cards.

media.credit: A. Lyddiatt, D. Peacock and D. Boulter (1978)

text.headline: First tree built from protein sequences by computer
text.text: In the 1966 edition of The Atlas, Dayhoff and Eck publish a phylogenetic tree relating organisms by the protein cytochrome c, including yeast, tuna, kangaroo and human. This tree offers more realistic estimates of branch lengths than subsequent work.

text.headline: Point-accepted mutation (PAM) matrices
text.text: In the 3rd volume of The Atlas, Dayhoff and Eck describe a method to estimate the evolutionary distance between two proteins. This highly influential model becomes a core component of BLAST.

media.url: â€˜Personally I believe that you are the kind of person who should become a member of the American Society of Biological Chemists. [However, the candidate must] demonstrate that he or she has done research which is clearly his own. The compilation of the Atlas [...] scarcely fits into this pattern.

text.headline: Dayhoff rejected from the American Society of Biological Chemists
Dayhoff begins to distribute The Atlas on magnetic tape
text.text: Due to a lack of grant support, Dayhoff decides to adopt commercial practices to support the cost of maintaining the database. In 1977, each Atlas tape was sold for $400. Like the book, these tapes were copyrighted and purchasers had to agree to not redistribute the database. Resentment builds in the scientific community.

text.headline: Public release of NCBI Genbank
text.text: Building on Dayhoff's work, Walter Goad and the Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) are awarded a grant to build a public database.  The initial release comprised about 2,000 sequence records.
